title: Introduction to statuAAR
text: Get df available formula measures. Check Breitinger & Bach 1965 documentation. Load data, e.g. Bach1965, data.frame. Prepare tabled data long list (statuaar_data_table). Check measurements using general statistics. Get stature estimations provided measurements. function returns list data frame formula.

what: Human statuar estimation from bone measures based on multiple formula
title: Human statuar estimation from bone measures based on multiple formula
text: R package calculate human stature estimation bone measurements. statuAAR can calculate human stature estimations according several well established formula based measured bone length. need table individuals rows measurements columns, repeated individual ID one measurement per row. Different formulas can selected data set, e.g. Breitinge & Bach 1956, Pearson 1899 Ruff et al. 2012, correspondig results provided list one data frame formula. date, large number formulas developed various bone measurements reference populations, yielding wide range possible results. quality result depends mainly representativeness original sample used formula relation data collection hand. straightforward quick calculation using different formulas allows easy comparison different results. general introduction human stature estimation based bone measurements can found, example, Ruff, Chr. B. (ed.) (2018). Skeletal variation adaptation Europeans: upper Paleolithic Twentieth Century. Hoboken, NJ: John Wiley & Sons. Siegmund, F. (2019). Die Körpergröße der Menschen der Ur- und Frühgeschichte Mitteleuropas und ein Vergleich ihrer anthropologischen Schätzmethoden. (Beiträge zur Archäologie des Lebensstandards, 1). Norderstedt: BoD. provide description formula, including required possible bone measurements citations (s. bibliography file BibTeX). Bone measurements designated according : Martin, R. (1928). Lehrbuch der Anthropologie systematischer Darstellung: mit besonderer Berücksichtigung der anthropologischen Methoden / für Studierende, Ärzte und Forschungsreisende. 3 vols. Fischer: Jena. package still development, basic workflow data preparation, verification calculation possible. Explanatory vignettes preparation.

title: Human statuar estimation from bone measures based on multiple formula
text: Get df available formula measures Check Breitinger & Bach 1965 documentation Read csv data, e.g. Bach1965.csv data.frame Prepare tabled data long list (statuaar_data_table) Check measurements using general statistics. Get stature estimations provided measurements. function returns list data frame formula. $bb65
code: statuAAR::getFormulaDataframe() ?statuAAR::breitinger_bach_1965 statuAAR::Bach1965 <- read.csv(     "data-raw/Bach1965.csv",     sep = ",",     header = TRUE,     skip=3,     stringsAsFactors = FALSE,     check.names = FALSE   ) dl.bach1965 <- statuAAR::prep.statuaar.data(Bach1965, d.form = "wide",                measures.names = "short", sex = "sex", stats = FALSE) statuAAR::measures.statistics(dl.bach1965) statuAAR::getStature(c('bb65'), dl.bach1965)

what: Calculate stature estimation according to Breitinger 1938 & Bach 1965. — breitinger_bach_1965
title: Calculate stature estimation according to Breitinger 1938 & Bach 1965. — breitinger_bach_1965
text: Stature estimation (mm) based mean different regression calculations, separated  sex (Breitinger 1938, Bach 1965). Bone measures used: Hum2, Hum1, Rad1b, Fem1, Tib1b. bone measures left right provided mean value used, statistic information 2 bones counted (n_measures). sex indet. mean male female stature estimation given. Breitinger (1938) show regression equation Hum1, equation can derived values given table p. 272 (see Siegmund 2010, p. 112). contrast, Bach (1965) gives equations. addition, Bach (1965, 20) states use one Humeri measures estimation (Hum1 Hum2 mean ) avoid inadmissable multiplication bone within stature estimation. Returns data.frame : ind: individual identifyer (rownames), sex: provided calculation: m, f, indet. stature: estimated provided sex bone measures, bone (measure(s)): bones used calculation, female (stature): columns alternative stature three sex classes, male (stature), indet. (stature) n_measures: number bone measures included: e.g. 2 Fem2 (left, right) + 1 Tib1

what: Calculate stature estimation according to: Byers et al 1989. — byers_etal_1989
title: Calculate stature estimation according to: Byers et al 1989. — byers_etal_1989
text: Stature estimation (mm) based regression calculation one Metatarsal 1 separated sex (Byers et al 1989). Bone measures used: Os metatarsale , apex capitulum midpoint articular surface base parallel longituninal axis bone. bone measures left right provided mean value used, statistic information 2 bones counted (n_measures). archaeological finds, group assignment (Euro-American Afro-American) possible. addition, gender-specific estimates Met1 offer best accuracy. reason, following formulas used: Combined data (indet): St = 634 + 16.8 (Metl), males: St = 815 + 14.3 (Metl), females: St = 783 + 13.9 (Metl). Returns data.frame : ind: individual identifyer (rownames), sex: provided calculation: m, f, indet. stature: estimated provided sex bone measures, bone (measure(s)): bones used calculation, female (stature): columns alternative stature three sex classes, male (stature), indet. (stature) n_measures: number bone measures included: e.g. 2 Met1 (left, right)

what: Calculate stature estimation based on bone measures according to: Formicola & Franceschi 1996. — formicola_franceschi_1996
title: Calculate stature estimation based on bone measures according to: Formicola & Franceschi 1996. — formicola_franceschi_1996
text: Stature estimation (mm) based hierarchical order regression calculations, separated  sex based : Fem2+Tib1, Fem1, Tib1, Hum1, Rad1. bone measures left right provided mean value used, statistic information 2 bones counted (n_measures). sex indet. mean male female stature estimation given. Formicola Franceschi (1996) provide information hierarchie mean calculation regression formula, table 3 gives standard error (S.E.) correlation hierarchical order can derived. order bone measures used according achieved correlation differs sex respected, allthough  differences small. Due , order used differs slightly Siegmund (2010, 116 (12.8)). Bone measures used: Fem2+Tib1, Tib1, Fem1, Hum1, Rad1 (Rad1a) Returns data.frame : ind: individual identifyer (rownames), sex: provided calculation: m, f, indet. stature: estimated provided sex bone measures, bone (measure(s)): bones used calculation, female (stature): columns alternative stature three sex classes, male (stature), indet. (stature) n_measures: number bone measures included: e.g. 2 Fem2 (left, right), 1 Tib1

what: Calculate stature estimation according to: Pearson 1899 — pearson_1899
title: Calculate stature estimation according to: Pearson 1899 — pearson_1899
text: Stature estimation (mm) based mean several multiple single regression calculations, separated  sex (Pearson 1899, p. 196). Bone measures used: Hum1, Rad1, Fem1, Tib1b, Tib1a bone measures left right provided mean value used, statistic information 2 bones counted (n_measures). sex indet. mean male female stature estimation given. According Pearson (1899, 196-97) following measure substitudes used: male: Fem1 = Fem2 + 3.2 mm, Tib1b = Tib1a - 9.6 mm female: Fem1 = Fem2 + 3.3 mm, Tib1b = Tib1a - 8.7 mm Pearson's work based bones right side. According measurements Rollet (1888) provides correction values bones left side. values vary male within +/- .4 - 4.2 mm female within +/- 0.4 - 5.1 mm. Leg length discrepancy (LLD) complex process due multiple causes environmental genetic factors increasing age. Based French data minor LLD often, treated cases 2 cm per leg. addition differences sex left vs right side observed (Guichet et al 1991, Holliday & Ruff 2001, Knutson 2005). consequence compounded correction left right bones values derived sample Rollet (1888) rejected. Returns data.frame : ind: individual identifyer (rownames), sex: provided calculation: m, f, indet. stature: estimated provided sex bone measures, bone (measure(s)): bones used calculation, female (stature): columns alternative stature three sex classes, male (stature), indet. (stature) n_measures: number bone measures included: e.g. 2 Fem2 (left, right) + 1 Tib1

title: statuAAR data preparation and check functions — readuserdata
text: Human stature estimation based various measures different bones. multitude formula developed provide wide range possible results. quality result depends mainly representativity original sample formula respect currrent study.  Thus easy fast forward calculation according various formula can used camparison results. measures given millimeters (mm). measures used defined R. Martin (1928). labels measures data aquisition may differ used statuAAR. Therefore concordance labels edited. addition summarised statistics measure across dataset provided check data inconsitancy befor calculation. create.measures.concordance: Creates data frame three columns: short names (e.g. Hum1al), long names (e.g. Humerus.1a.left) filled user defined names. measures.statistics: Calculates basic descriptive statistics check data consitancy. prep.statuaar.data: Checks input data: uniqueness individual identifyer, accepted values Sex accepted measures names. Provides data.frame standardised measurements calculation body stature estimation four columns: Ind(ividual), Sex, variable (mearsure name) value (measured value).

title: statuAAR data preparation and check functions — readuserdata
text: dl statuAAR data list provided prep.statuaar.data. x simple data.frame containing measurements per individual. d.form string defining data.frame structure. d.form=wide data.frame individuals (rows) measurements (columns). d.form=long  data.frame one measure per individual one row. two columns: variable(character, measure name e.g. hum1), value (numeric, length (mm)), row represents one individual one measurement identified row number. ind string defining column identifiers individual. ind = NA column Ind rownumbers added. sex string defining column identifying sex. sex = NA column Sex indet added. measures.names string defining set predefined measure names used. data.frame measures.concordance correlation (merge) needed. measures=short: Bone (3 letters), measure acc. Martin (1928), laterality (1 letter) without separation (e.g. Hum1, Hum1l, Hum1r, Hum1a, Hum1al, Hum1ar etc.). measures=long: Bone measure acc. Martin (1928), laterality separated . (e.g. Humerus.1, Humerus.1.left, Humerus.1a.left, etc.). measures=: data.frame measures.concordance names merged needed. stats Output aggregating statistics measures provided. Default = TRUE.

title: statuAAR data preparation and check functions — readuserdata
code: # Read example dataset into a data frame  # Read example dataset into a data frame x <- TrotterGleser1952 # If not yet existent create a list of measure names to be used # measures.concordance <- create.measures.concordance() # Edit the measures.concordance (not needed for this dataset) # measures.concordance$own[measures.concordance$short=="Fem1"]<-"Fem"  # get a dataframe with measures to process dl.trotter.gleser <- prep.statuaar.data(x, d.form = "wide",    ind = "Appendix_row", sex = "Sex", measures.names = "own", stats = FALSE) # See basic statistics to check for errors measures.statistics(dl.trotter.gleser) #> # A tibble: 5 × 8 #>   measure     n  MinM Quart1 MedianM MeanM Quart3  MaxM #>   <chr>   <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl>   <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl> <dbl> #> 1 Fem1      184   348    414     464   465    514   605 #> 2 Hum1      184   244    291     328   328    364   417 #> 3 Rad1      184   165    217     248   250    282   340 #> 4 Tib1      184   271    328     374   375    418   511 #> 5 Uln1      184   193    235     266   268    298   364  # For the data from Rollet 1888 rollet1888 <- Rollet1888 # 1. Create an identifyer due to identical numbering of females and males rollet1888$id<-paste(rollet1888$Sex, rollet1888$Nr, sep="_") # 2. Fill in the mesasures names in the column "own" of the measures.concordance measures.concordance <- measures.concordance.rollet1888 # 3. Read the data dl.rollet1888 <- prep.statuaar.data(rollet1888, d.form = "wide",       ind="id", sex = "Sex", measures.names = "own") #> # A tibble: 1 × 8 #>   measure     n  MinM Quart1 MedianM MeanM Quart3  MaxM #>   <chr>   <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl>   <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl> <dbl> #> 1 NA          0    NA     NA      NA   NaN     NA    NA
